articles.headline: Officer’s Death Stuns Illinois Town a Second Time
articles.snippet: More than two months after Lt. Charles Gliniewicz was found dead, officials said he took his own life, fearing he was about to be caught for stealing money from the town.
articles.abstract: More than two months after Lt. Charles Gliniewicz was found dead, officials said he took his own life, fearing he was about to be caught for stealing money from the town.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shooting death of a police lieutenant made national news and brought a stretch of northern Illinois to a tense standstill with roadblocks, thudding helicopters and officers tramping with dogs through woods and over farmland, searching for the killers. The lieutenant, Charles J. Gliniewicz, was hailed as a hero, and some conservatives seized on this and other shootings as evidence that critics of the police were fueling a wave of violence against law enforcement.

articles.headline: December Interest Rate Increase Is ‘a Live Possibility,’ Janet Yellen Says
articles.snippet: Janet Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, told a House committee that the economy was “performing well” and that an interest rate increase “may be appropriate.”
articles.abstract: Janet Yellen, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, told a House committee that the economy was “performing well” and that an interest rate increase “may be appropriate.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve could raise its benchmark interest rate in December as long as economic growth continues, two senior Fed officials said on Wednesday, hammering that message in repeated public remarks.

articles.headline: Britain, Concerned About Russian Crash, Halts Sinai Flights
articles.snippet: Prime Minister David Cameron announced the suspension of all flights between Britain and the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron announced the suspension of all flights between Britain and the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government on Wednesday suspended flights between Britain and the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh over concerns that a chartered Russian jetliner might have been brought down in the Sinai Peninsula by a bomb on board.

articles.headline: Marco Rubio Confronts New Scrutiny Over Use of Party Credit Card
articles.snippet: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said that he would “soon” release additional records that would detail expenditures from a Republican Party credit card used years ago, brushing aside continued criticism about his personal finances.
articles.abstract: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said that he would “soon” release additional records that would detail expenditures from a Republican Party credit card used years ago, brushing aside continued criticism about his personal finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade after he began using a Republican Party credit card for personal purchases like paving stones at his home, Senator Marco Rubio on Wednesday pledged to disclose new spending records from that account as he sought to inoculate himself against what could be his biggest liability as a presidential candidate: how he manages his finances.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Ruling in Mexico Sets Into Motion Legal Marijuana
articles.snippet: Ruling that individuals should have the right to grow and distribute marijuana for personal use, the court waded into the debate on the war on drugs.
articles.abstract: Ruling that individuals should have the right to grow and distribute marijuana for personal use, the court waded into the debate on the war on drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Mexican Supreme Court opened the door to legalizing marijuana on Wednesday, delivering a pointed challenge to the nation’s strict substance abuse laws and adding its weight to the growing debate in Latin America over the costs and consequences of the war against drugs.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Malkin and Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: Activists May Be Less Myopic Than Their Reputation Suggests
articles.snippet: While activists have been criticized for short-term “quarterly capitalism,” they may hold shares longer than many institutional or retail investors.
articles.abstract: While activists have been criticized for short-term “quarterly capitalism,” they may hold shares longer than many institutional or retail investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are activist investors short-term traders or in it for the long term? It is the question of the moment as nearly $200 billion has poured into the coffers of activists with names like Icahn, Ackman and Peltz, among others. Last year, as a group they put some 200 companies in their cross hairs and replaced 19 chief executives, according to the law firm Sidley Austin, putting pressure on virtually every board in the country to pay attention to this vocal class of shareholders.

articles.headline: Bitcoin Surges, Emerging From a Lull in Interest
articles.snippet: Despite its use for illegal activities, Bitcoin is being closely studied by conventional banks and financial firms. The online currency has rallied over 100 percent in the last month.
articles.abstract: Despite its use for illegal activities, Bitcoin is being closely studied by conventional banks and financial firms. The online currency has rallied over 100 percent in the last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a long period of quiet, the price of the virtual currency Bitcoin is surging again as signs of interest from China and Wall Street have helped kick off a new speculative frenzy.

articles.headline: Airbnb and Uber Mobilize Vast User Base to Sway Policy
articles.snippet: Leading companies in the sharing economy, like Airbnb and Uber, are turning their millions of users into an enormous political operation to fight back against unfavorable policies.
articles.abstract: Leading companies in the sharing economy, like Airbnb and Uber, are turning their millions of users into an enormous political operation to fight back against unfavorable policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last few years, so-called sharing companies like Airbnb and Uber — online platforms that allow strangers to pay one another for a room or a ride — have established footholds in thousands of communities well before local regulators have figured out how to deal with them.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis and the 1975 Law Complicating Matters
articles.snippet: The Tower Amendment, a law passed to ease a constitutional dispute in 1975, has made solving Puerto Rico’s debt crisis even more difficult.
articles.abstract: The Tower Amendment, a law passed to ease a constitutional dispute in 1975, has made solving Puerto Rico’s debt crisis even more difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: To appreciate why it is proving so hard for Washington to help debt-burdened Puerto Rico, it helps to go back to 1975, the year New York City went broke, and consider the role played in that crisis by a prominent Republican senator from Texas named John Tower.

articles.headline: Trans-Pacific Partnership Text Released, Waving Green Flag for Debate
articles.snippet: Opposition mainly came from an array of unions and environmental groups, but some big businesses, like Ford, also joined the emerging resistance to the pact.
articles.abstract: Opposition mainly came from an array of unions and environmental groups, but some big businesses, like Ford, also joined the emerging resistance to the pact.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The release on Thursday of the full text of President Obama’s trade accord with 11 Pacific Rim nations brought out opponents and supporters and officially opened what may be the last big battle of the president’s tenure: winning congressional approval of the largest regional trade deal in history.

articles.headline: Red Tape Slows U.S. Help for Children Fleeing Central America
articles.snippet: A program to offer a legal way into the United States for Central American children fleeing violence has yet to admit a single child into the country.
articles.abstract: A program to offer a legal way into the United States for Central American children fleeing violence has yet to admit a single child into the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama vowed a year ago to give Central American children fleeing violence a new, legal way into the United States by allowing them to apply for refugee status while in their own countries instead of accepting help from smugglers or resorting to a dangerous trek across Mexico.

articles.headline: Adele’s Album Will Be Big. But Will It Be Streaming?
articles.snippet: The elite artist’s choice will reflect the industry’s larger debate over how fully to embrace the streaming format.
articles.abstract: The elite artist’s choice will reflect the industry’s larger debate over how fully to embrace the streaming format.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Adele’s millions of fans, perhaps the biggest question about her next album is whether its songs will pack the same emotional wallop that helped make her last record a global smash.
